data.text:
Bridgeville, Delaware History - City Information

Bridgeville Delaware is a charming and ideal town served by two major highways, route 13 and 404. It is a tiny little town that was settled as early as 1684 as Attawattacoquin, on a piece of land given from Charles Calvert the third, Lord Baron of Baltimore. Before the town received it's final name of Bridgeville in 1871, it was also known as Bridge Branch. The town itself was incorporated in 1938 and is now a growing community filled with rich history, east coast beauty and friendly people.

There is no light like the amber light of the Autumn season. The cool, breezy air is abundant with the feeling of change and excitement, beckoning us back to our childhood years and our memories of 'back to school', new clothes and lunch boxes filled with our favorite foods. It is a time of reuniting with old friends and the alluring aromas of fresh baked cookies and homemade breads, all bringing that 'feel good' factor to our souls. Another joy of the fall season is Bridgeville's Annual Apple-Scrapple festival in October. This gladsome fall celebration is filled with a delightful food court, street dancing, a carnival, live music, tattoo contests as well as a trade and car show. Other events at this fete include a 5K Hogg jogg, a scrapple chunkin' contest, annual pig-out and a craft show. It surely promises to give everyone a wonderful time and is an idealistic way to begin the cherished season of autumn.

Bridgeville has many renown restaurants in it's neighboring cities, but also hosts some great eateries within it's own borders. For some good old-fashioned home cooking that will warm the heart and soul, the Bridgeville Diner is a favorite as well as Jimmy's Grille. Next door, is the historic city of Seaford. This enchanting city is the largest city in Delaware and was voted to be the 'Best small town in America'. It offers it's guests an awesome River Walk with 400 feet of serene, landscaped park land with paved sidewalks, sending an invitation for all to come and stroll along the river and refresh both the body and soul! For those who enjoy being on the water, there is also a canoe launch for canoing on the river. Seaford offers plenty of game for those who love to hunt with their bountiful supply of geese, deer, rabbit, squirrel, dove and raccoon.

Another neighboring city to Bridgeville is the romantic Georgetown. This city is known as "The Historic Jewel of Sussex County". A wonderful time to visit is during the cities celebration of 'Return Day'. Two days after election day, visitors gather from all around the state to hear the results of the election and enjoy a delightful celebration with parades, speeches, music, arts and a savory and delicious Ox Roast. This city is known for it's abundance of history. While visiting, be sure to see The Circle, the old and new courthouse, historic buildings and the National Historic Register of Homes. Also the Paynter House, Mansion House and Benton Harris House are a must see while your in town.

Bridgeville is only a matter of minutes away from the renown beach cities of Lewes and Rehoboth. These two cities offer an abundance of amenities for both residents and guests alike during all four seasons. From beautiful golf courses, water parks, tax free shopping, (Tanger Outlets), four star restaurants, coffee pubs, antique stores, fitness centers, to historic lighthouses, museums and art galleries, the beach cities have it all. With in a few short hours one can see the historic cities of Baltimore, Annapolis, Washington DC, Wilmington and Philadelphia. These cities are well worth the drive with beautiful views of the Chesapeake Bay and Atlantic ocean, Winterthur Gardens, famous museums, monuments and wonderful eateries with cuisine that draws tourists from all over the country.

Whether one is looking for a perfect vacation spot, or a place to relocate to that is full of beauty and rich history, surronded by cities that offer a wealth of things to do and places to see, Bridgeville is a quaint town with much to offer people of any age!
